xxl.core.relational.cursors
Class Renaming

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.cursors.SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
      xxl.core.relational.cursors.Renaming
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.util.Iterator<Tuple>, Cursor<Tuple>, MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>, MetaDataProvider<CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>
public class Renaming
extends SecureDecoratorCursor<Tuple>
implements MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>>

Straight forward implementation of the operator renaming.

In earlier versions of XXL it was possible to hand over a string array to the constructor of the operators instead of an array of indices. To get this functionality, use ResultSets.getColumnIndices(ResultSet, String[]).

The example in the main method wraps an enumeration (integers 0 to 9) to a metadata cursor using Cursors.wrapToMetaDataCursor(java.util.Iterator, Object). Then, the column becomes renamed to "NewName" and the cursor is printed on System.out. The interesting call is: 

   cursor = new Projection(
       cursor,
       ArrayTuple.FACTORY_METHOD,
       new int[] {
           1
       },
       new String[] {
           "NewName"
       }
   );

Constructor Detail

Renaming

public Renaming(MetaDataCursor<Tuple,CompositeMetaData<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> cursor,
                int[] columns,
                java.lang.String[] newNames)
Creates a new instance of renaming. The specified columns of the of the tuples derived from the underlying metadata cursor are renamed using the given names.

Parameters:
cursor - the input metadata cursor delivering the input elements.
columns - an array of column numbers that become renamed.
newNames - an array holding the new column names.
